title: I just finished writing a manuscript. Should I send my work to more than one publisher at the same time? - Quora

response.answer_text: To approach a Top 10 US publisher (the Big 5 + 3 independents + 2 non-fiction presses), you will pretty much need a literary agent. (There are a few open submission times, but I can’t remember the last time I heard about a deal coming about this way). There are lots of good threads on how to get a literary agent here, but one thing I would caution, before querying them, is to not just have finished writing a manuscript. You want that ms to have gone through at least a few drafts steered by your own revision process, which should include putting it away in a cyber drawer for a time, coming back to it, then doing this again (and again). You want it to be copy edited for smooth, typo-free copy. And you want some independent readers to have given you honest, thoughtful, critical feedback—the more the better—and then, after a period of time to consider it all, to have gone back to the ms and incorporated everything you decided would make the book better. You can ask for independent reads from friends and family, as long as they will be HONEST, and you can also find book clubs and ask if they’ll tear into—and tear apart—your ms, perhaps with a few boxes of doughnuts or bottles of wine for enticement and thanks for the great service they’ll be giving you. Yes, of letting you do yet more work…but also having the consequently best chance of success once you do start querying agents. Finally, you can join a writers group and trade reads—either IRL or online—although proceed with caution because sometimes writers read a ms as a writer and not as a reader, which can be both a good and a bad thing. Once you have readers telling you they stayed up all night reading your ms…congratulations! You are now ready to find the right agents and start sending out targeted queries. Good luck!

ABSOLUTELY NOT!!!! What happens if both of ’em say “We love it!” and you have to say “Uh, well, someone else wants to buy it, too?” You can end up pissing off both publishers and losing out with both of them AND get your name informally listed as a PITA. Send it to one publisher at a time, get a clear acceptance or rejection, and then and only then move on to the next publisher if necessary. Multiple submissions should only be done by an agent at their discretion because they know how to do it.
